column2: V. Captain Littlepage
column3: V. Captain Littlepage

column2: IT WAS A long time after this; an hour was very long in that coast town where nothing stole away the shortest minute.
column3: IT WAS A long time after this; an hour was very long in that coast town where nothing stole away the shortest minute.

column2: I had lost myself completely in work, when I heard footsteps outside.
column3: I had lost myself completely in work, when I heard footsteps outside.

column2: There was a steep footpath between the upper and the lower road, which I climbed to shorten the way, as the children had taught me, but I believed that Mrs. Todd would find it inaccessible, unless she had occasion to seek me in great haste.
column3: There was a steep footpath between the upper and the lower road, which I climbed to shorten the way, as the children had taught me, but I believed that mrs Todd would find it inaccessible, unless she had occasion to seek me in great haste.

column2: I wrote on, feeling like a besieged miser of time, while the footsteps came nearer, and the sheep-bell tinkled away in haste as if someone had shaken a stick in its wearer's face.
column3: I wrote on, feeling like a besieged miser of time, while the footsteps came nearer, and the sheep bell tinkled away in haste as if someone had shaken a stick in its wearer's face.

column2: Then I looked, and saw Captain Littlepage passing the nearest window; the next moment he tapped politely at the door.
column3: Then I looked, and saw Captain Littlepage passing the nearest window; the next moment he tapped politely at the door.

column2: Come in, sir, I said, rising to meet him; and he entered, bowing with much courtesy.
column3: Come in, sir, I said, rising to meet him; and he entered, bowing with much courtesy.

column2: I stepped down from the desk and offered him a chair by the window, where he seated himself at once, being sadly spent by his climb.
column3: I stepped down from the desk and offered him a chair by the window, where he seated himself at once, being sadly spent by his climb.

column2: I returned to my fixed seat behind the teacher's desk, which gave him the lower place of a scholar.
column3: I returned to my fixed seat behind the teacher's desk, which gave him the lower place of a scholar.

column2: You ought to have the place of honor, Captain Littlepage, I said.
column3: You ought to have the place of honor, Captain Littlepage, I said.

column2: A happy, rural seat of various views,
column3: A happy, rural seat of various views,

column2: he quoted, as he gazed out into the sunshine and up the long wooded shore.

column2: Then he glanced at me, and looked all about him as pleased as a child.

column2: My quotation was from Paradise Lost: the greatest of poems, I suppose you know? and I nodded.
column3: My quotation was from Paradise Lost: the greatest of poems, I suppose you know? and I nodded.

column2: There's nothing that ranks, to my mind, with Paradise Lost; it's all lofty, all lofty, he continued.
column3: There's nothing that ranks, to my mind, with Paradise Lost; it's all lofty, all lofty, he continued.

column2: Shakespeare was a great poet; he copied life, but you have to put up with a great deal of low talk.
column3: Shakespeare was a great poet; he copied life, but you have to put up with a great deal of low talk.

column2: I now remembered that Mrs. Todd had told me one day that Captain Littlepage had overset his mind with too much reading; she had also made dark reference to his having "spells" of some unexplainable nature.
column3: I now remembered that mrs Todd had told me one day that Captain Littlepage had overset his mind with too much reading; she had also made dark reference to his having "spells" of some unexplainable nature.

column2: I could not help wondering what errand had brought him out in search of me.
column3: I could not help wondering what errand had brought him out in search of me.

column2: There was something quite charming in his appearance: it was a face thin and delicate with refinement, but worn into appealing lines, as if he had suffered from loneliness and misapprehension.
column3: There was something quite charming in his appearance: it was a face thin and delicate with refinement, but worn into appealing lines, as if he had suffered from loneliness and misapprehension.

column2: He looked, with his careful precision of dress, as if he were the object of cherishing care on the part of elderly unmarried sisters, but I knew Mari' Harris to be a very common-place, inelegant person, who would have no such standards; it was plain that the captain was his own attentive valet.

column3: He sat looking at me expectantly.

column2: I could not help thinking that, with his queer head and length of thinness, he was made to hop along the road of life rather than to walk.
column3: I could not help thinking that, with his queer head and length of thinness, he was made to hop along the road of life rather than to walk.

column2: The captain was very grave indeed, and I bade my inward spirit keep close to discretion.
column3: The captain was very grave indeed, and I bade my inward spirit keep close to discretion.

column2: Poor Mrs. Begg has gone, I ventured to say.
column3: Poor mrs Begg has gone, I ventured to say.

column2: I still wore my Sunday gown by way of showing respect.
column3: I still wore my Sunday gown by way of showing respect.

column2: She has gone, said the captain,--"very easy at the last, I was informed; she slipped away as if she were glad of the opportunity."
column3: She has gone, said the captain,--"very easy at the last, I was informed; she slipped away as if she were glad of the opportunity."

column2: I thought of the Countess of Carberry, and felt that history repeated itself.

column2: She was one of the old stock, continued Captain Littlepage, with touching sincerity.

column2: She was very much looked up to in this town, and will be missed.

column2: Captain Littlepage moved his chair out of the wake of the sunshine, and still sat looking at me.
column3: Captain Littlepage moved his chair out of the wake of the sunshine, and still sat looking at me.

column2: I began to be very eager to know upon what errand he had come.

column2: In that handful of houses they fancy that they comprehend the universe.

column2: I smiled, and waited for him to go on.

column2: I am an old man, as you can see, he continued, "and I have been a shipmaster the greater part of my life,--forty-three years in all.
column3: I am an old man, as you can see, he continued, "and I have been a shipmaster the greater part of my life,--forty three years in all.

column2: You may not think it, but I am above eighty years of age."
column3: You may not think it, but I am above eighty years of age."

column2: He did not look so old, and I hastened to say so.
column3: He did not look so old, and I hastened to say so.

column2: You must have left the sea a good many years ago, then, Captain Littlepage? I said.
column3: You must have left the sea a good many years ago, then, Captain Littlepage? I said.

column2: I should have been serviceable at least five or six years more, he answered.
column3: I should have been serviceable at least five or six years more, he answered.

column2: I do not mind telling you that I chanced to learn of one of the greatest discoveries that man has ever made."
column3: I do not mind telling you that I chanced to learn of one of the greatest discoveries that man has ever made."

column2: Now we were approaching dangerous ground, but a sudden sense of his sufferings at the hands of the ignorant came to my help, and I asked to hear more with all the deference I really felt.

column2: A swallow flew into the schoolhouse at this moment as if a kingbird were after it, and beat itself against the walls for a minute, and escaped again to the open air; but Captain Littlepage took no notice whatever of the flurry.
column3: A swallow flew into the schoolhouse at this moment as if a kingbird were after it, and beat itself against the walls for a minute, and escaped again to the open air; but Captain Littlepage took no notice whatever of the flurry.

column2: I had a valuable cargo of general merchandise from the London docks to Fort Churchill, a station of the old company on Hudson's Bay, said the captain earnestly.
column3: I had a valuable cargo of general merchandise from the London docks to Fort Churchill, a station of the old company on Hudson's Bay, said the captain earnestly.

column2: Then the fog kept us off the coast; and when I made port at last, it was too late to delay in those northern waters with such a vessel and such a crew as I had.

column2: I owned an eighth of the vessel, and he owned a sixteenth of her.

column2: She was a full-rigged ship, called the Minerva, but she was getting old and leaky.
column3: She was a full rigged ship, called the Minerva, but she was getting old and leaky.

column2: I meant it should be my last v'y'ge in her, and so it proved.

column2: She had been an excellent vessel in her day.

We left Fort Churchill and run out into the Bay with a light pair o' heels; but I had been vexed to death with their red tape rigging at the company's office, and chilled with stayin' on deck an' tryin' to hurry up things, and when we were well out o' sight o' land, headin' for Hudson's Straits, I had a bad turn o' some sort o' fever, and had to stay below.

column2: Captain Littlepage spoke with a kind of slow correctness that lacked the longshore high flavor to which I had grown used; but I listened respectfully while he explained the winds having become contrary, and talked on in a dreary sort of way about his voyage, the bad weather, and the disadvantages he was under in the lightness of his ship, which bounced about like a chip in a bucket, and would not answer the rudder or properly respond to the most careful setting of sails.
column3: Captain Littlepage spoke with a kind of slow correctness that lacked the longshore high flavor to which I had grown used; but I listened respectfully while he explained the winds having become contrary, and talked on in a dreary sort of way about his voyage, the bad weather, and the disadvantages he was under in the lightness of his ship, which bounced about like a chip in a bucket, and would not answer the rudder or properly respond to the most careful setting of sails.

column2: So there we were blowin' along anyways, he complained; but looking at me at this moment, and seeing that my thoughts were unkindly wandering, he ceased to speak.

column2: It was a hard life at sea in those days, I am sure, said I, with redoubled interest.

column2: I see a change for the worse even in our own town here; full of loafers now, small and poor as 'tis, who once would have followed the sea, every lazy soul of 'em.
column3: I see a change for the worse even in our own town here; full of loafers now, small and poor as 'tis, who once would have followed the sea, every lazy soul of 'em.

column2: There is no occupation so fit for just that class o' men who never get beyond the fo'cas'le.

column2: I view it, in addition, that a community narrows down and grows dreadful ignorant when it is shut up to its own affairs, and gets no knowledge of the outside world except from a cheap, unprincipled newspaper.

column2: A shipmaster was apt to get the habit of reading, said my companion, brightening still more, and taking on a most touching air of unreserve. "A captain is not expected to be familiar with his crew, and for company's sake in dull days and nights he turns to his book.

column2: Most of us old shipmasters came to know 'most everything about something; one would take to readin' on farming topics, and some were great on medicine,--but Lord help their poor crews!--or some were all for history, and now and then there'd be one like me that gave his time to the poets.
column3: Most of us old shipmasters came to know 'most everything about something; one would take to readin' on farming topics, and some were great on medicine,--but Lord help their poor crews!--or some were all for history, and now and then there'd be one like me that gave his time to the poets.

column2: I was well acquainted with a shipmaster that was all for bees an' beekeepin'; and if you met him in port and went aboard, he'd sit and talk a terrible while about their havin' so much information, and the money that could be made out of keepin' 'em.
